item.title: MTV Simulator Features 25,000+ Music Videos And Is Very Cool
item.content:encoded:
Today, MTV is a zombie network that primarily airs episodes of Ridiculousness and random Paramount-owned comedy films. It‚Äôs depressing. But before all that, before The Real World and Road Rules, MTV was a channel that mostly played music videos, and it was cool. So I was happy to hear that someone has created a free MTV simulator website, complete with retro ads.

MTV Rewind is a website that tries to recreate the experience of watching the original music channel back in the day. When you first visit the site, it starts playing the original MTV broadcast, complete with VJ introductions and the original music videos that were aired on that faithful day back in August 1981. I wasn‚Äôt alive back then, but it‚Äôs still fun to relive that launch from the comfort of my PC in 2025.

Beyond recreating the first day, MTV Rewind features different decades you can swap between, built up of playlists featuring thousands of videos, as well as random, old TV ads from back in the day. And I have to admit, there is something special and comforting about returning to an era in which music was delivered to me without me having to create playlists, seek out artists, or hear the stuff that some algorithm decides I want to listen to next. Just a hose of old music videos streamed directly into my ears. Cool shit.

The creator of MTV Rewind says they built this project, which uses YouTube for all the videos, over the course of a week as a ‚Äúpassion project.‚Äù They shared on Reddit that they have ‚Äúa deep nostalgia‚Äù for MTV and miss the 24/7 music videos. I‚Äôm happy they took the time to make this site. Now, if you‚Äôll excuse me, I have a lot of 1990s music to jam out to while I work.

item.title: Stranger Things‚Äô Big Finale Fight Was Inspired By Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3
item.content:encoded:
The Stranger Things season five finale ends with a big fight involving the major players of the series, and according to the creators behind the hit Netflix show, how this large fight played out was inspired by Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3. 

Last week, on New Year‚Äôs Eve, Stranger Things wrapped up after nearly a decade with an epic two-hour finale. While some fans weren‚Äôt happy with the conclusion and are even theorizing that a special bonus episode will be released soon, the last episode of Stranger Things did deliver a big battle featuring Vecna, the Mind Flayer, and many of the characters people have grown to love over the last few years.

In a new interview with Variety, the Duffer brothers, the duo behind the show and its finale, revealed that the big boss fight was inspired by playing Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3. 

‚ÄúWe were thinking about D&D, and I was playing Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 [while creating the finale], and we felt it was very important that the only way for them to defeat it was for the entire party to work together,‚Äù said Matt Duffer. ‚ÄúEveryone had fully realized‚Äîeither through self-acceptance or they‚Äôve resolved all their various issues‚Äîmoving into that final battle, they‚Äôre absolutely primed. They‚Äôre the ultimate team, and it‚Äôs the party working all together to defeat this thing. And they each have their own individual skills, right? And that‚Äôs where I go back to Dungeons & Dragons, and something like Baldur‚Äôs Gate. Because that‚Äôs how you take down these monsters that seem otherwise unstoppable.‚Äù

Swen Vincke, the head of the studio behind Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3, seemed pleased with this information, resharing it on Twitter and saying, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs pretty cool.‚Äù

While speaking to Variety, Matt Duffer also added that ‚Äúlots of video game references were applied to that final battle,‚Äù but didn‚Äôt confirm anything specific. Also, it sounds like the Duffers are aware of your wild theories that the ‚Äútrue‚Äù finale is yet to be revealed and simply replied, ‚ÄúObviously, that‚Äôs not a real thing.‚Äù

item.title: Escape From Tarkov Dev Trolls Players By Making Its Impossible Ending Even More Brutal
item.content:encoded:
Skip to content

Escape From Tarkov Dev Trolls Players By Making Its Impossible Ending Even More Brutal

After player feedback said that the ending was too ruthless, developer Battlestate Games made it even more so

Escape From Tarkov

After a long, eight-year wait, players can finally escape from Tarkov in Escape from Tarkov. However, reaching the new end-game location, Terminal, is no easy feat, and neither is battling your way through to its conclusion. And now, following complaints from some in the Escape from Tarkov community who found escaping too difficult, developer Battlestate Games has decided to make things even harder.

As part of the long-awaited 1.0.0.2 update on December 1st of last year, Battlestate Games added four unique endings to Escape from Tarkov‚Äôs gruelling 200-ish hour-long campaign. Battling through the chaotic wave of AI-controlled enemies is no simple task, especially since you‚Äôve just been stripped of all your gear, but things become all the more punishing once you reach Terminal‚Äôs final hurdle. And according to PCGamesN, after some players said they found it too challenging, the devs decided that it actually still sounded a bit too easy.

If you‚Äôve yet to complete Terminal for yourself, be warned that we‚Äôre about to get into heavy spoiler territory here.

When Escape from Tarkov‚Äôs full release update dropped, it added a brutal decision that players had to make: a boat had to be taken to reach the titular escape, but it only fit three. The game‚Äôs standard player formation is squads of five. Thus, two people had to stay behind, becoming engulfed in a nuclear blast while others sail away to safety (and earning themselves one of Escape from Tarkov‚Äôs ‚Äúbad‚Äù endings).

Naturally, considering all the work it takes to get to that point, a sizable chunk of the community complained online. This included Escape from Tarkov streamer Velion, who wrote, ‚ÄúI would really like to see this changed where everyone can escape together. Imagine being able to go into terminal and meeting 2 other players who you work together on a hard map and you survive and make it out.‚Äù Directing his feedback squarely at Battlestate Games, he tagged studio head Nikita Buyanov in his Twitter post.

Buyanov immediately replied by simply stating ‚Äúits changed already,‚Äù which would reasonably lead you to assume that leaving Tarkov with all your buddies is now an option.

Turns out that Buyanov considers himself a comedian, as he actually meant that things have ‚Äúchanged‚Äù for the worse. As other players online have already pointed out, the number of players who can now escape at the end of Terminal has been whittled down to one.

Of course, you could just play through Terminal by yourself and not have to bother with the hassle of deciding which of you gets to live once it ends, but that feels like it defeats the point. Escape from Tarkov has always been a game about forging bonds and making friends, and watching them all get consumed by a nuclear blast while you sail off into the sunset, Titanic-style, just seems fitting.

item.title: Logan Paul‚Äôs Pitch For A Pok√©mon Game Is Nostalgia Brain Poison
item.content:encoded:
I don‚Äôt pay much attention to Logan Paul, the content creator turned wrestler with side hustles that involve turning Pok√©mon cards into heartless cash grabs and a failed NFT game. But the social media persona entered my field of view last night after making a now viral post pitching his idea for a new Pok√©mon game. Well, ‚Äúnew‚Äù is a stretch, considering what he‚Äôs asking for is essentially another fucking remake of the original Pok√©mon Red and Blue games. But having been in the series‚Äô vicinity for almost 30 years, I know that this is the type of artless pitch lapsed and casual Pok√©mon fans would happily gobble down like Moomoo Milk.

Pushing aside with all our might that this reads like a pitch to Game Freak that was probably written by ChatGPT (‚Äúnostalgic equity‚Äù is a phrase no human has ever said), let‚Äôs look at what Paul is actually asking for.

Idea for The Pok√©mon Company:

I think there is a MASSIVE opportunity to capitalize on the decades of nostalgic equity that fans have with the franchise

The same frenzy that originally propelled Pok√©mon into mainstream culture lives within millions of adults that yearn for the‚Ä¶

‚Äî Logan Paul (@LoganPaul) January 5, 2026

He says that The Pok√©mon Company has a ‚Äúmassive opportunity‚Äù to bank on nostalgia, as if Pikachu and friends have ever not taken the opportunity to shove the original Kanto starters into something over the past 30 years. He also mentions how, every few years, he‚Äôll boot up the original games on a Game Boy to find ‚Äújust as much joy‚Äù playing back through them as he had as a child. 

He then admits he doesn‚Äôt have ‚Äúmuch of a connection‚Äù to newer Pok√©mon, which is where he begins to give the game away. He does like Annihilape and Baxcalibur, suggesting he‚Äôs not completely out of the loop. But since he doesn‚Äôt really seem to care about anything Pok√©mon has done in the last 27 years, he argues it would be cool for Game Freak to create ‚Äúremastered‚Äù versions of the Generation I Game Boy games, with ‚Äúadaptive NPCs that evolve alongside the player.‚Äù

He says they could even use modern technology to let players connect to the internet for trading and battling, something Pok√©mon has literally been doing for 20 years, ever since Diamond and Pearl on the DS. He goes on:

This will do three things

1.) Give older fans a chance to relive their childhood thus awakening a massive, dormant demographic 

2.) Give newer, younger fans a taste of what originally made the franchise so special

3.) Bridge the gap for older fans who don‚Äôt connect with newer Pok√©mon in a way that‚Äôs familiar to them

If we believe that video game cycles are like a pendulum, the near-future of gaming may birth a desire for more simplified, block-based aesthetics. We already see it happening with games like Minecraft & Roblox. As technology continues to advance at an alarmingly rapid pace, I personally believe the future will lean towards ‚Äúretro‚Äù

This LinkedIn-ass post tries to intellectualize what is obvious nostalgia-pining as some kind of market inevitability; that it would just be good business sense for Pok√©mon to go back to Kanto for the people who only played those original games decades ago, outgrew them, and now think the problem is that the all-ages franchise has fallen ‚Äúbehind the times.‚Äù Also, crucially, Game Freak already remade those original games twice with FireRed/LeafGreen and the Let‚Äôs Go games on Switch, the latter of which are only seven years old.

Yes, the original Red and Blue are still the best-selling games in the franchise, and maybe some people are too young to realize that the level of Pok√©mania back then was far beyond the still massive success Pok√©mon enjoys right now. To insinuate that Pok√©mon is in danger of getting away from its base of ‚Äò90s kids, though, is like saying the sun isn‚Äôt shining because you‚Äôre inside and can‚Äôt feel its warmth. But this is the sentiment of a lot of retired Pok√©mon trainers who stopped playing in elementary school and mistake their own lack of interest for the series no longer having the sauce.

It‚Äôs the same mentality that makes people mad that Scarlet and Violet have ‚Äúregular animals‚Äù in them like Flamigo when Red and Blue had Seel, or who didn‚Äôt like that Gen V and VI had Pok√©mon made of ‚Äúobjects‚Äù when Grimer and Voltorb were literal sludge and a living Pok√© Ball. Pok√©mon made me feel something specific as a child, and now that I‚Äôm an adult and my brain has developed differently, I don‚Äôt feel that way anymore. Instead of the realities of adulthood crushing my spirit, it must be because the Pok√©mon games don‚Äôt have Professor Oak and Misty in them all the time.

If all you‚Äôre looking at is video game sales numbers, you probably could foolishly think Pok√©mon is ‚Äústruggling‚Äù in the market compared to what it hit in the ‚Äò90s, despite the absolute trashfire that was Scarlet and Violet still readily selling around 27 million copies, a number any other company would kill to hit. But Pok√©mon is a lifestyle brand that makes most of its money from merchandise sales, and you would think someone who played a major role in inflating the value of the trading cards would know that.

Honestly, if people like Paul want something that feels just like the old games did when they were five, try a ROM hack. Fans have been making retro-style Pok√©mon games for decades. They‚Äôre not only great, they‚Äôll probably also make you feel cozy-wozy with their pixelated graphics that look like what you played on your Game Boy. And hey, you can probably find plenty that don‚Äôt include all the hundreds of new Pok√©mon you don‚Äôt like, but which millions of younger players grew up on and hold as dear as old-timers do Pikachu or Charmander.

This yearning for the mines of Kanto exists around the periphery of Pok√©mon every day, and it‚Äôs only going to ratchet up more this year with the series‚Äô 30th anniversary celebrations already paying tribute to those old games. ROM hacks, mock-ups from people who don‚Äôt even like the games anymore, and even fan art are constantly gesturing at the series‚Äô old aesthetics. I still have my original copy of Pok√©mon Yellow sitting on my shelf to this day, and maybe if Game Freak releases those old games on Switch this year, I‚Äôll play it again. 

But I don‚Äôt need The Pok√©mon Company to keep looking back. And the company certainly doesn‚Äôt need to tap into a ‚Äúmassive,‚Äù untapped well of fair-weather fans who will come back to the franchise for good if they remake Red and Blue again. I think it‚Äôll live.
